FacilityName: H. B. Fuller - Blue Ash Plant

_chemical.ChemicalName: Vinyl acetate monomer  [Acetic acid ethenyl ester]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



1.0    Introduction



H. B. Fuller manufactures waterbase polymer emulsions at the Blue Ash facility.  This 

process combines monomers along with other chemicals in a specified vessel to form the 

finished adhesive product.  



2.0    Regulated Substances



Vinyl acetate monomer (VAM) is the only chemical listed in the Clean Air Act 112 (r) 

and used above its threshold value at this site.  VAM is transported to the site primarily 

through tanker trucks and, occasionally, railcars.  Two dedicated tanks located within a 

secondary containment are used to store the VAM.  This raw material is introduced into 

the process through piping, pumps, and intermediate vessels prior to being metered into 

the reactors where it is polymerized into the finished product.



3.0    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Chemical releases are minimized through a variety of means including operator training, 

equipment design and installation, initial startup, operating procedures, and maintenance 

procedures.  It is the policy of the Blue Ash facility to identify the potential for chemical 

releases and address their causes.  In the unlikely event a release occurs the facility 

personnel are trained in operational parameters to minimize the effects without 

compromising their own safety.



4.0    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Steps



This facility has taken the steps identified in 40 CFR 68 to reduce or minimize the effects 

of any accidental release.  These processes which use VAM are also subject to the 

requirements of the Process Safety Management regulations found in 29 CFR 1910.119.  

The following paragraphs briefly describe the current release prevention program for the 

process which polymerizes VAM.



Process Safety Information

This information describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment 

design for the associated processes.



Process Hazard Analysis

This is a systematic review of the process by a cross functional team used to ensure the 

hazards of the process are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used in 

these analyses is the HAZOP technique.  The identified recommendations are reviewed, 

prioritized and implemented in a timely manner.



Operating Procedures

Operating procedures are used to safely produce products in an effective and repeatable 

manner.  These procedures address the  various stages of the operation including initial 

startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency operations, normal 

shutdown, emergency shutdown, process sequencing, and startup after a shutdown.  The 

procedures are periodically reviewed and are readily accessible to the operators.



Mechanical Integrity

Maintenance of the equipment requires a variety of methodology.  Testing and studies are 

performed equipment such as vessels and piping to determine that it continues to meet its 

design capabilities; inspections are performed on devices such as rupture disks and vents 

to ensure they are operational; periodic maintenance is used on that equipment (pumps, 

controls, valves, etc.) which is used regularly.  Qualified personnel are used to perform 

these maintenance operations.  Should a deficiency be identified during any one of these 

processes it is addressed in a timely and safe manner.



Management of Change

Changes in the process are proposed, described, and reviewed with through written 

procedures.  Changes can be a change in chemical, technology, equipment or procedure.  

Those affected by the change are notified and trained, if necessary.



Pre-startup Review

Prior to a new process startup the installation, equipment, operating and maintenance 

procedures are reviewed to ensure they are suitable for safe operations.  



Compliance Audit

Audits are used to identify any shortcomings in the existing program in comparison to the 

regulations and allow for contin

uous improvement.  These occur at least every three 

years.  Any corrective actions are undertaken in a safe and timely manner.



Incident Investigation

Reportable incidents are investigated and reviewed promptly.  The purpose of the 

investigation is to record the steps leading up to the incident, identify any abnormal or 

unusual conditions and develop effective corrective actions to prevent similar incidents 

from occurring.  The reports are maintained for at least five years.



Employee Participation

Active participation of operators, maintenance mechanics, facility management and 

corporate personnel is both required and encouraged.  Additional forums such as 

employee involvement teams, safety meetings and business meetings are used in inform 

and interact with individuals.  



Contractors

Some projects or tasks require additional manpower or specialized skills more efficiently 

provided by contractors.  These contractors are made aware of the potential hazards 

related to the contract work and operation.  



 



5.0  Five Year Accident History



There have been no reportable accidents or releases as define in 40 CFR 68.42 over the 

preceding 5-year period.



6.0    Emergency Response Program



The Pre-Emergency Plan was written to address abnormal situations such as employee 

injury and chemical release.  The text includes procedures to address emergency 

response, evacuation of employees, notification of governmental agencies, and medical 

responses.  It is reviewed annually and updated to reflect any pertinent changes which 

occasionally occur at the facility.



A secondary part of the program is the installation and operation of equipment which will 

stop an emergency event, minimize its effects or allow evacuation from a process area.  

The equipment includes a monitored sprinkler system, fire detecting devices and fire 

extinguishers.  These systems are regularly inspected and serviced in order to maintain 

their reliability.

7.0    Planned Safety Improvements



Safety improvements are identified through a continuous process that utilizes 

preventative maintenance program, process hazard analyses and management of change 

procedures, audits as well as employee observations and operations review.  Potential 

improvements are evaluated for corollary effects and implemented if practical, improved 

the process, and does not cause safety issues elsewhere.
